course_name: NE452 - Special Topics in Nanoscale Simulations (0.50)
major_name: Chemistry - Computational Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Special Topics in Nanoscale Simulations Winter 2025
Dr. Subha Kalyaanamoorthy
Email: subhak@uwaterloo.ca

Topics in this theme area may include: an overview of modern computational methods and algorithms in nanoscale materials, such as steered molecular dynamics, ab initio molecular dynamics, multiscale modelling, dissipative particle dynamics, transition path sampling, phase-field modelling, quantum simulations using Feynman path integral techniques, condensed-phase spectroscopy, linking of simulations to experiment, simulations and their practical applications.
This course provides a comprehensive introduction to molecular simulations, emphasizing their application in bionanotechnology.
Students will explore the fundamental concepts of biomolecular structure, gaining insights into proteins, lipid membranes, and other biomolecules relevant to nanoengineering.
The course delves into molecular simulation techniques, focusing on molecular dynamics (MD) simulations as a core method for studying biomolecular interactions, dynamics, and properties.
Advanced topics include enhanced sampling techniques such as umbrella sampling and metadynamics, which address challenges in exploring complex energy landscapes and rare events.

Real-world examples from bionanotechnology applications will highlight the role of molecular simulations in solving engineering challenges, such as understanding nanoparticle-biomolecule interactions, studying transport phenomena through lipid membranes, and designing nanostructures for drug delivery and biosensing.
Through lectures, hands-on practicals, and case studies, students will develop the skills to apply molecular simulations to analyze and innovate within the field of bionanotechnology.
Describe the structural and functional properties of biomolecules such as proteins, lipid membranes, and polymers, emphasizing their relevance in nanoengineering applications.
Gain hands-on experience on different software programs such as Visual Molecular Dynamics, Chimera, Pymol that can be used for structure and simulation analyses
Perform molecular dynamics simulations of different types of molecules and investigate complex free energy landscapes and rare molecular events
Examine molecular transport through lipid membranes and nanopores, applying simulations to understand key properties and mechanisms.
Model and interpret the interactions between nanoparticles and biomolecules, understanding their implications for bionanotechnology applications such as drug delivery
Week 1-2 : Introduction to Biomolecular structure and interactions
Week 7-8 : Molecular simulations and Molecular dynamics [
Week 10-12 : MD simulations for bionanotechnology

topics: Notice of Recording

Selected topics in HVAC systems design with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability.

Constant- and variable-flow systems.

Selected topics in HVAC systems design, with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability: heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems; constant- and variable-flow systems; heat- and energy-recovery systems; vapor-compression heat-pump systems, including air-and geothermal-source heat pumps.
Course Overview: Achieving significant reductions in building energy consumption will be important in efforts to deal with the environmental and socioeconomic impacts of energy use.
The energy used by heating, ventilating, and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems represents a large portion of the energy consumption of most commercial, institutional, and residential buildings.

This course will introduce selected topics in HVAC systems design, with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability: heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems; constant- and variable-flow systems; heat- and energy-recovery systems; vapor-compression heat-pump systems, including air- and geothermal-source heat pumps.

Recommended Preparation: It is strongly recommended that students have engaged in prior study of introductory concepts in thermodynamics, heat transfer, and fluid mechanics, including analysis of refrigeration cycles and basic psychrometrics.
Students without this background are expected to undertake additional study to acquire sufficient competency in each topic.

topics: Energy and the Environment Fall 2024
Drop-in Hours: TBD in E2 2315; online (MSTeams) by request
Conservation of energy, energy balances on closed systems.
Phase change in natural environmental systems; The basics of heat engines, refrigerators, and heat pumps.
Problems of thermodynamics and energy are regularly encountered by environmental engineering professionals.
Basic knowledge of thermodynamics, the science of energy, is required to solve and understand many problems in water resources, wastewater treatment, air pollution, and energy harvesting.
We are likewise tasked with dealing with the air, water, and soil pollution that are a common by-product of energy extraction and utilization.

The objective of this course is to introduce you to theoretical and practical aspects of energy transport and work in both natural and manmade systems, and learn how to estimate heat/energy transfer and energy consumption in these systems.
Develop basic mass and energy balances for closed systems
Be familiar with critical concepts in thermodynamics: energy, enthalpy, mechanical and electrical work, specific heat, entropy
Estimate magnitudes of conductive, convective, and radiative heat transfer in natural and engineered systems
Calculate energy required for phase change in environmental systems
Understand the basic functioning of a range of renewable and non-renewable energy technologies (e.g., photovoltaics, wind & water turbines, geothermal systems, nuclear power plants, biofuel, etc.).
Be able to perform simple calculations to estimate the efficiency of heat engines, refrigerators, and heat pumps.
Apply simplified design approaches to select renewable energy technologies
Understand the issues with, and be able to compare, energy technologies in terms of their environmental impact and energy costs
Be familiar with the basic issues of energy policy

major_name: Civil Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: jclausen@uwaterloo.ca (please do not use the D2L email system)
I monitor my email M-F, 9:00 am - 5:00 pm.
I am teaching multiple communication courses, and especially early in the sememster, I cannot always quickly know whch course you are referring to just from your email.
In this course students in Architectural, Civil, Environmental, and Geological Engineering will enhance oral and written communication competencies in contexts relevant to the engineering profession.
In this course, you will work to enhance your written and oral technical communication competencies in contexts relevant to the engineering profession as well as to your future career.

More generally, in this course, you should anticipate learning what professional norms of technical communication and dominant forms of sharing knowledge prevail within and across the fields of engineering.
Yet this course also attempts to impart awareness and appreciation for how these communicative forms are matters of social context and sites of negotiation and contestation.

By extension, this progression also encourages you to find a place and voice in the conversations within your fields of study and to reflect upon the meaning and shape of available forums for technical communication.
I perceive our classroom as a co-constructed space, in which readings and discussions may frequently challenge your attitudes, your unconsciously held beliefs, or your positions on current issues.
To ensure a safe and open space in which all can converse and learn productively, it is vital that we conduct our relationships with respect and an ethic of care.
Describe and apply conventions, genres, norms, and values of communication in an engineering discipline;
Compose persuasive, audience-specific technical arguments;
Analyze and summarice technical content in clear and concise ways;
Deliver effective oral presentations; and
Appraise and reflect on their own compositions, and those of their peers, to strategically revise and edit documents and presentations
Objectives for Students of Communication Studies
You (students) will understand the complexity of communication as a human process of shared meaning-making in the context of power, history, and culture.

You will increase your capacity to recognize and enhance yours and others’ agency – the ability to make a difference in the world for yourself and others – and understand the implications of your communication behaviors for yourself and others.
Recognize diverse linguistic practices and modes of communication as resources for writers and speakers.

You will understand communication as a practice, and improve your critical and creative communication competencies by developing your ability to use writing, speaking, and other media of communication to create effective and engaging artifacts.

Your will reflect on your role in fostering the public good (the multifaceted well-being of individuals and groups), begin to imagine a better future, and make decisions in your communication that can transform the communities to which you belong.

In this assignment, you will choose a specific topic related to civil engineering and identify an overarching problem to produce a project proposal.

In this assignment you will creating a proposal in response to an imagined request for proposals (RFP) from a contractor in the industry, and presenting that proposal in a short three-minute pitch for your classmates, who will consider the persuasiveness of your proposal.
Failures of retaining walls

Role of surveying in engineering
In groups of 2 or 3, you will provide a technical summary of that element for a public, non-specialist audience.
You will present a summary of the project element as a poster presentation on a standard 24x36 inch poster board using a combination of written and graphic communication.

We may be involved in a public displaying of the posters we create, alongside students from other sections of Engineering Communication on evening in February over in one of the Engineering buildings.
Part 2: Research Abstract
The abstract should provide information relevant to solutions to the problem you articulated in your proposal and continue to advocate for a particular solution/recommendations.
For the final project you will create a policy brief aimed at a clear stakeholder audience.
Instructions
A formal policy brief includes the following sections:
Executive summary
Explanation of results
identify and address a specific policy-making audience
explain the current research on this topic in clear, non-technical language
highlight the features of the research most relevant for policy makers and stakeholders
make one or two recommendations based on your synthesis of the research
Natural Resource Development
Climate Change Impact
Mass Transportation Design

Communicative competencies will play a significant role in distinguishing the most successful engineers from others who are equally skilled technicians but who lack the ability to communicate effectively.
You will hand-in a 200 word individual reflection on the process of translating engineering concepts for a public non-expert audience.
You should reflect on what skills, competencies and concepts you used in creating your final project.

The course develops a geological knowledge for applications to any physical environment and provides an appreciation of the impact of engineering work on the environment.
Topics include mineral and rock identification, the rock cycle, structural geology and tectonics, geology of Canada, effects of water, ice and wind.
Students are also introduced to the concept of geologic time, topographic and geologic maps, and the basic principles and tools used to determine geologic history.
Gain insight into why engineers are continually challenged by the science behind a complex and changing earth.
Understand and apply engineering design principles in the context of a changing earth.
Gain basic experience in identifying earth materials and in earth material testing.
Establish the academic background required to take advanced earth sciences and geotechnical engineering courses.
Geology and Soils Labs: This course includes seven laboratory sessions that will be held during the term.

The course develops a geological knowledge for applications to any physical environment and provides an appreciation of the impact of engineering work on the environment.
Topics include mineral and rock identification, the rock cycle, structural geology and tectonics, geology of Canada, effects of water, ice and wind.
Students are also introduced to the concept of geologic time, topographic and geologic maps, and the basic principles and tools used to determine geologic history.
Gain insight into why engineers are continually challenged by the science behind a complex and changing earth.
Understand and apply engineering design principles in the context of a changing earth.
Gain basic experience in identifying earth materials and in earth material testing.
Establish the academic background required to take advanced earth sciences and geotechnical engineering courses.

topics: Compound stress and stress transformations.

The Statics portion of the course mainly involves three-dimensional force system analysis and the Solid Mechanics course content is focused on examining material response (i.e., stress and strain conditions) in different sections/members under external loads.
Specific topics include transverse shear, torsion of shafts, treatment of compound stresses, and the introduction of beam deflections and basic design concepts.

The primary objective of this course is to provide students with conceptual knowledge to analyse simple structural systems and to evaluate the mechanical response of the structural components comprising these systems.
Calculate distributions and magnitudes of stresses in elements subjected to shear, torsion, bending, and combinations thereof
Construct axial force, shear force, and bending moment diagrams for beams and frame elements
Determine deflected beam shapes and compute the magnitudes of deflections at key locations
Design simple beams to satisfy strength and/or service criteria

major_name: Civil Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Engineering and Sustainable Development Spring 2024
nadine.ibrahim@uwaterloo.ca
nadine.ibrahim@uwaterloo.ca
This course introduces the concept of sustainability and how it applies to decision-making in civil engineering.
The course begins by defining sustainability, both practically and technically, and describing the concepts of systems, and systems interactions.
Economic concepts and their applicability to sustainability are described for both developed and developing countries.
Sustainability concepts covering the triple bottom line are presented, and their applicability to sustainability are described.
First, the qualitative concepts and background information is presented.
I’ll be teaching sustainable development and its connection to engineering using both a qualitative and quantitative understanding of sustainability.
Qualitatively, this involves describing sustainability objectives, trends, current conditions and future projections, and to have a technical and public understanding of sustainability challenges.

Quantitatively, this involves modeling environmental parameters using linear programming, differential equations, regression and extrapolation, and understanding the metrics used for sustainability assessments.
I believe students have different strengths, where the diversity of coursework will leverage individual strengths and give everybody a chance to shine!
I encourage you to read the announcements on a regular basis and stay up to date.
IDENTIFY: Identify implications of human activities on the three dimensions of sustainability
QUANTIFY: Quantify sustainability indicators to assess trade-offs
DEMONSTRATE: Demonstrate course concepts to assess sustainability in global cities
Relate course concepts to everyday activities and living experiences

topics: Fluid Mechanics Spring 2024
john.quilty
lmarquez
An introduction to fluid mechanics.
Fluid properties.
The momentum equation and applications.
Pump systems.

This course introduces and reviews the subject of fluid mechanics including topics such as pressure and forces in static fluids, buoyancy, laminar and turbulent flow regimes, continuity, energy and momentum conservation, steady pipe flow and energy losses, and simple pump systems.
Characterize fluids and fluid systems based on their properties and system variables
Analyze static fluid systems to calculate pressures, forces and moments acting on submerged surfaces and objects, and floating objects
Use and judge mathematical models of simple dynamic fluid systems using the principles of mass, energy, and force/momentum conservation
Analyze simple pipe and pump systems for viscous liquids
Communicate laboratory findings effectively
Introduction – Dimensions and Systems of Units; Fluid properties: measures of mass, weight, compressibility, viscosity, surface tension and vapour pressure 1.1-1.9

Fluid Statics – Pressure: pressure at a point; spatial variation; Absolute and gauge pressure, manometers; Pressure forces: forces & moments on planar and curved surfaces; Buoyancy and stability 2.1-2.11

Mass and Energy Conservation –  Control volumes and surfaces, stream tubes, uniform & non-uniform flow; Mass conservation: continuity equation; Energy conservation: Bernoulli & energy equations, real fluids, energy losses and gains 5.1, 5.3.3

Viscous Flow in Pipes – Reynolds number; Steady uniform flow and flow resistance: force and energy balance; Laminar and turbulent flow in pipes: flow equations, frictional losses, Moody diagram, single pipe flow solution methods; Minor losses in pipes: changes in pipe diameter or geometry, flow control devices;
Pipes in series and parallel
Pipe Networks – Hardy-Cross method
Momentum Conservation – Linear momentum equation, applications 5.2.1-2

Coverage includes hypothesis testing and the nature of scientific inquiry, basic population genetics, physiological ecology, life histories, dispersal, basic population and community ecology, macroevolution, systematics and classification, as well as functional morphology.
The theory of evolution unites the whole of biology and all living organisms into a coherent body of knowledge, allowing comparisons across all forms of life.
Ecology describes how organisms interact with their environment and each other to create interdependent systems from microscopic to global scales.

These disciplines are fundamentally tied together: evolution is the primary mechanism by which species adapt to their environment; ecological interactions and environmental variability drive natural selection.

You will also carry out simulated lab assignments to test the principles of evolution, design ecological experiments to test alternate hypotheses about the conservation of species and manipulate demographic parameters to test their influence on population growth.
Understand the principles of scientific methodology
Define ecological and evolutionary terms, such as the niche, adaptation, and altruism
Illustrate these mechanisms in the context of course examples
Explain how ecological interactions and evolution are interconnected

This unit serves as an introduction to the study of the function of the five organ systems examined in this course (nervous, muscular, cardiovascular, respiratory, and immune).
Unit 1 will introduce how the organ systems work together to maintain homeostasis within the body.
The organization of the nervous system will be explored in this unit.
The types of cells found in the central and peripheral nervous system serve as a starting point to discuss their function within the nervous system.
Initially gross structure of skeletal muscle including the structure of a muscle fibre and myofibrils will be examined.
An exploration into the muscle contraction mechanism via excitation-contraction coupling will be examined to explain how muscles work.
This unit will start with an introduction into the heart and components of the cardiovascular system, which will be followed by cardiac muscle contraction mechanism.
In this unit we will examine the structure and function of the respiratory system, incorporating gas laws and ventilation.
Pulmonary function through lung compliance and elastance as well as the control of ventilation will be examined.
This unit will start with the general function of immune system and introduction to the types of pathogens that infect the body.
The anatomy of the immune system will be discussed returning to the role of haematopoiesis.

Introduces the main concepts and principles of ecology; the cycling of elements; energetics and structural organization of major ecological systems; population dynamics; impact of natural resource management practices and urban and industrial development on the environment; incorporating environmental quality considerations into development activities.
The lab sessions include field trips to study natural and disturbed ecosystems, urban and applied ecology.
View requirements for ENVS 200

Such knowledge, called ecoliteracy, will provide a critical basis for your engagement in the 21st century, the “century of the environment”—not least because so many of the environmental issues we face derive in part from a limited understanding of how we are embedded within and dependent upon ecological systems.

Field ecology necessarily harbours an ethical component both because of our natural affinity for life (or ‘biophilia’) and because questions of ecological ‘impact’ and 'quality’ are necessarily value-laden.

In summary, this course introduces the main concepts and principles of ecology; the cycling of elements; energetics and structural organization of major ecological systems; population dynamics; impact of natural resource management practices and urban and industrial development on the environment; incorporating environmental quality considerations into development activities.
The lab sessions include field trips to study natural and disturbed ecosystems, urban and applied ecology.
By the end of this course, you should be on a path to life-long learning as an ecologically-literate citizen.

Articulate the elements of scientific inquiry as they apply to ecology/

These course learning outcomes will not only prepare you to be an informed citizen and member of the community of life on earth, but also provide the basis for knowledge, humility, and wisdom in your dealings with ecological problems in your daily life and eventual career.

We will explore some of the big-picture questions pertinent to each section, which are some of the most important driving forces behind all of science.
Some of the main questions in each section are:
Is there life elsewhere in the Universe?

major_name: Civil Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Environmental Geology Winter 2024
Include Earth 221 in the subject line and your full name and student ID# in the text.

An introduction to geological concepts; the influence of geological factors on the natural environment; Earth processes and natural hazards; Earth resources, including water, energy and mineral resources; waste disposal and pollution; global climatic and environmental change.
Environmental Geology refers to how geologic processes interact with and influence human activities and vice versa.
The goal is to introduce you to basic geologic concepts in order to better understand your natural physical surroundings, such as earthquakes, volcanoes, surface water and glacial processes.
You will also learn about resource availability such as groundwater and fossil fuels and how we impact the environment via waste disposal and other forms of pollution.

As the population of the Earth grows, there is increased demand for limited supplies of natural resources, a growing release of pollutants, and increased development in geologically unstable parts of the world.
These issues result in a variety of hazards and potential problems that societies need to understand and deal with in ways that are beneficial for the Earth and local populations.
Explain the geologic/earth science connections to certain environmental issues
Use geologic terminology and concepts when describing environmental issues
Critique the use of scientific information in the public domain (e.g., media) regarding geologically-related environmental issues

topics: Building Energy Analysis Fall 2024
Introduction to whole-building energy analysis.
Energy auditing, benchmarking, and simulation.

The course is intended to help students develop knowledge and skills that will be useful in analyzing and diagnosing the energy use of buildings, with the general objectives of reducing environmental, economic, and social impacts of energy use.
Topics will be presented from a multi-disciplinary perspective, as the design, construction, and operation & maintenance of buildings are all multi-disciplinary endeavors.
Relevant concepts in thermodynamics and heat transfer will be reviewed.
Selected building systems and components will be studied, including aspects of building envelope, lighting, and HVAC systems.

course_name: AE573 - HVAC Systems, Equipment, and Energy Efficiency (0.50)
major_name: Civil Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
HVAC Systems, Equipment, and Energy Efficiency Winter 2025
Selected topics in HVAC systems design with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability.
Heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems.
Constant- and variable-flow systems.
Heat- and energy-recovery systems.
Vapour-compression refrigeration and heat-pump systems (including air- and geothermal-source heat pumps).

Selected topics in HVAC systems design, with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability: heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems; constant- and variable-flow systems; heat- and energy-recovery systems; vapor-compression heat-pump systems, including air-and geothermal-source heat pumps.
Course Overview: Achieving significant reductions in building energy consumption will be important in efforts to deal with the environmental and socioeconomic impacts of energy use.
The energy used by heating, ventilating, and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems represents a large portion of the energy consumption of most commercial, institutional, and residential buildings.

This course will introduce selected topics in HVAC systems design, with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability: heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems; constant- and variable-flow systems; heat- and energy-recovery systems; vapor-compression heat-pump systems, including air- and geothermal-source heat pumps.

Recommended Preparation: It is strongly recommended that students have engaged in prior study of introductory concepts in thermodynamics, heat transfer, and fluid mechanics, including analysis of refrigeration cycles and basic psychrometrics.
Students without this background are expected to undertake additional study to acquire sufficient competency in each topic.
Perform simple thermodynamic calculations for selected HVAC components and systems.
2. Explain operational characteristics of selected energy-saving strategies for HVAC systems.
3. Assess the potential for selected energy-saving strategies to operate effectively for a variety of operating conditions and applications.

major_name: Civil Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Traffic Simulation Modelling and Applications Fall 2024
RCH 306
Email: reza.aminghafouri@uwaterloo.ca
Calibration and validation of simulation models, and interpretation and analysis of simulation output.
Applications of state-of-the-art computer simulation software packages for solving real traffic engineering problems, involving scenario analysis, prediction, and optimization.
This is an introductory course to traffic engineering, traffic simulation and the processes and tools used to model transportation systems.

It covers a variety of topics related to simulation modelling of a traffic system and its applications, such as the collection and use of field data, application of statistics to data analysis, alternative traffic modelling techniques such as traffic stream theory, queueing theory, gap acceptance, and car-following and lane-changing models.
Learn various field data collection technologies and data analysis techniques to support traffic engineering studies.

topics: Structural Steel Design Spring 2024
Advanced coverage of design of structural steel members and connections, building on CIVE 310.
Design of laterally-unsupported beams, compression members and beam-columns.
Special topics in design of structural steel or other metals.
The primary objective of the course is to provide students an introduction and a solid background in the principles of limit states design for structural steel.
Emphasis will be placed on behaviour and design of steel members for buildings.
Bases of the criteria given in the CSA S16-2019 will be studied.
Analyse and design structural steel beams, columns and tension members for considering both strength and serviceability requirements
Analyse and design members subjected to combined bending and axial forces, including second-order effects
Design simple plate girder elements
Analyse and design simple connections using welds or bolts
